error.signature: toomanyrequests: You have reached your pull rate limit. You may increase the limit by authenticating and upgrading: https://www.docker.com/increase-rate-limit
error.regex: (?i)(?:toomanyrequests|pull rate limit|rate limit.*exceeded|429 Too Many Requests.*docker)

verdict.summary: Docker Hub rate limits were exceeded for anonymous or free-tier pulls. Anonymous pulls are limited to 100 per 6 hours per IP; authenticated free users get 200. CI environments sharing IPs hit this quickly.

dead_ends.action: Waiting for the rate limit to reset without implementing a long-term fix
dead_ends.why_fails: The rate limit will be hit again on the next CI run cycle since the underlying pull pattern has not changed

dead_ends.action: Using a VPN or rotating IPs to bypass the rate limit
dead_ends.why_fails: This violates Docker Hub terms of service and is unreliable. Shared CI runner IPs still converge on the same rate limits.

workarounds.action: Authenticate with Docker Hub to increase the rate limit
workarounds.how: Create a Docker Hub account and add credentials to CI. For GitHub Actions: store DOCKER_USERNAME and DOCKER_PASSWORD as secrets, add a docker/login-action step before pulls. This doubles the rate limit to 200 pulls/6hr.

workarounds.action: Use a registry mirror or cache proxy
workarounds.how: Set up a pull-through cache registry (e.g., registry:2 with proxy.remoteurl=https://registry-1.docker.io). Or use cloud provider mirrors: AWS ECR Public, GitHub Container Registry (ghcr.io), or Google Mirror (mirror.gcr.io).

leads_to.condition: when rate-limited base image pulls cause Dockerfile FROM to fail
when attempting to authenticate to avoid rate limits but credentials are misconfigured

preceded_by.condition: when failed authentication falls back to anonymous pulls which then hit rate limits

frequently_confused_with.distinction: docker-rate-limit is about exceeding pull quotas; docker-login-failed is about authentication credential errors
